lines.content: This is a project template for a greenfield Java project. It's named after the Java mascot _Duke_. Given below are instructions on how to use it.
Prerequisites: JDK 11, update Intellij to the most recent version.
1. Open Intellij (if you are not in the welcome screen, click `File` > `Close Project` to close the existing project first)
1. Open the project into Intellij as follows:
1. Select the project directory, and click `OK`.
1. If there are any further prompts, accept the defaults.
1. Configure the project to use **JDK 11** (not other versions) as explained in [here](https://www.jetbrains.com/help/idea/sdk.html#set-up-jdk).
In the same dialog, set the **Project language level** field to the `SDK default` option.

3. After that, locate the `src/main/java/duke.Duke.java` file, right-click it, and choose `Run duke.Duke.main()` (if the code editor is showing compile errors, try restarting the IDE). If the setup is correct, you should see something like the below as the output:
Deadline(String description, boolean isDone, String deadline) {
* The Duke class is a chatbot that controls and manages your todo list application
public void run() throws DukeException, IOException {
public static void main(String[] args) throws DukeException, IOException {
* Custom Exception for Duke related Errors
Event(String description, boolean isDone, String time) {
* Parser executes all actions passed from the Ui class
* prints the list of currently stored tasks
System.out.println("Here are the tasks in your list:");
* finds and prints task based on whether it contains the given keyword
* @param keyword word to be matched with task description
System.out.println("Here are the matching tasks in your list:");
* marks the chosen task as done and prints a confirmation
* @param taskNumber represents which task to mark, 1 for the first task, 2 for the second, etc
System.out.println("Nice! I've marked this task as done:");
* unmarks the chosen task and prints a confirmation
* @param taskNumber represents which task to unmark, 1 for the first task, 2 for the second, etc
System.out.println("OK, I've marked this task as not done yet:");
* adds the given ToDo object and prints a confirmation
* @param toDo ToDo object to be added to TaskList
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:\n"
+ String.format("Now you have %d tasks in the list."
* adds the given Deadline object and prints a confirmation
* @param deadline Deadline object to be added to TaskList
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:\n"
+ String.format("Now you have %d tasks in the list."
* adds the given Event object and prints a confirmation
* @param event Event object to be added to TaskList
System.out.println("Got it. I've added this task:\n"
+ String.format("Now you have %d tasks in the list."
* deletes task at a specified position and prints a confirmation
* @param number represents which task to delete, 1 for the first task, 2 for the second, etc
+ String.format("Now you have %d tasks in the list."
* In charge of reading to file on start up and writing to file on update
* Converts a txt file into a TaskList object
* @return TaskList object that contains all tasks saved in the hard disk
static TaskList readFile() throws DukeException, IOException {
throw new DukeException("Data file could not be created");
private static void addLineToTasks(String currLine, TaskList listOfSavedTasks) {
* Converts the given TaskList object and saves it onto the hard disk as a txt file

static void saveToFile(TaskList tasks) throws IOException {
* Abstract class representing a task object to be saved in TaskList
return (isDone ? "X" : " "); // mark done task with X
* Converts Task to String form to be printed
* @return String to be printed to console
* TaskList is a class that manages the storage of tasks inside the application
* Ui is a class that the user interacts with on the CLI
* This method will handle user input from the CLI, it has multiple commands such as
* list, mark, unmark, todo, deadline, event, delete, bye
throw new DukeException("OOPS!!! The description of " +
"but I don't know what that means :-(");
System.out.println("Bye. Hope to see you again soon!");
assertEquals("[D][X] do week 3 iP (by: Jan 23 2022)", new Deadline(" do week 3 iP", true, "2022-01-23").toString());
assertEquals("[E][X] attend lecture (at: Jan 23 2022)", new Event(" attend lecture", true, "2022-01-23").toString());
assertEquals("[T][X] return book", new ToDo(" return book", true).toString());
